block.p: California Approves Plan To Cut Vehicle Emissions California regulators approved a plan aimed at sharply reducing emissions of global warming gases from cars and trucks over the next 11 years.

It would be the first such regulation in the nation and one that, if it survives legal challenges, would force automakers to significantly increase the fuel efficiency of millions of vehicles. [Page A1.]

Faith-Based Health Care Offered The Bush administration has broken new ground in its faith-based initiative, this time by offering federal employees a Catholic health plan that excludes payment for contraceptives, abortion and sterilization. [A1.]

Oil Prices Trim Gains for Stocks Blue-chip stocks ended barely higher as a spike in oil prices to near-record levels pared earlier gains and renewed concerns about the effect of high energy prices on consumer spending and corporate profits. [C4.]

Europe Is Said to Clear Oracle Deal The European Union's competition commissioner, Mario Monti, is ready to allow Oracle to proceed with its $7.7 billion hostile takeover bid for PeopleSoft in the coming weeks, people close to the case said. [C2.]

Publisher of Maxim Dismisses 15 Dennis Publishing USA, which publishes the magazines Maxim and Stuff and the music magazine Blender, dismissed 15 executives and editors in an effort to cuts costs. [C4.]
Orders for Durable Goods Drop Orders to factories for big-ticket goods dropped in August, weighed down by a decline in demand for commercial airplanes. [C4.]
Regulators Weigh Morningstar Suit Securities regulators may file a suit against Morningstar over incorrect data it published about a mutual fund, the company said. [C3.]

Chip Sales Slide at Philips Signaling a possible wider slowdown in the semiconductor industry, Royal Philips Electronics became the latest company to say that its chip sales had begun to stall, at least temporarily. Having once predicted a spike of up to 4 percent, Philips's semiconductor division said third-quarter sales in dollars would not exceed this year's second-quarter result of $1.72 billion. [C2.]

Companies May Bid for Yukos President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia said that state-run companies might bid for assets of Yukos in any sale to collect back taxes, raising the prospect of further government control over the nation's oil and gas industry. [C2.]
Pressure to Succeed at HBO Can HBO keep soaring? Despite its dominance at the recent Emmy awards, rival television executives say they are not so sure. [B11.]

Mining Company in Merger Talks Noranda, Canada's largest mining company, said that it was in talks that might lead to its acquisition by the China Minmetals Corporation in a deal worth about $4.7 billion. [C2.]
A Judge Rules Against United A federal bankruptcy court judge ruled against United Airlines in a procedural dispute with unions over employee pensions. [C2.]
Alitalia Plan to Split Progresses Alitalia said eight of its nine biggest unions agreed to a plan to split the airline in two. [C2.]
Surgical Device No Longer Made St. Jude Medical said it would stop making a device used during heart surgery. [C4.]

Chart: ''YESTERDAY'' Dow industrials -- 10,047.24 up 8.34 Nasdaq composite -- 1,879.48 down 6.95 10-yr. Treasury yield -- 4.03% up 0.01 The euro -- $1.2268 down 0.0460 The dollar -- 110.68 yen up 0.13
Graph tracks the daily closing price of Royal Phillips Electronics shares for the week.
Graph tracks the daily closing of the Dow Jones Industrials since January.
(Source by Bloomberg Financial Markets)
